text: Describe some strategies you used to solve percent problems.

Strategies will vary.

Students might use percent bar/tape diagrams, proportions, tables with equivalent percentage amounts, multiplying by the fraction, or decimal form of the percent.

Students should mention that you scale percents like you do with other proportional relationships.

Describing similar and different will vary. Students might discuss the following:

Different

  • Percents are always part-to-whole. Ratios can be part-to-part or part-to-whole.
  • Percents always have one of the quantities equal to 100. This is helpful for comparing. Ratios can have different wholes, so you may have to scale to find an equivalent quantity to compare.

Similar

  • Percents have one of the two quantities equal (whole of 100), so you can compare the other quantity. This is like finding a unit rate or scaling a ratio to get one of the two quantities the same.
  • You can scale percents like you do any ratio or rate.
